bibl.title: Despatch from William D. McCoy to William F. Wharton, March 31, 1892
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: Consulate of the United States Monrovia, Liberia, March 31, 1892.
William D. McCoy, to the Assistant Secretary of State.
Request for Blanks, supplies, and Newspapers.
Consulate of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, March 31, 1892.
Honorable WIlliam F. Wharton, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington, D. C.

Sir: I respectfully request of you the following blanks, supplies, and newspapers for use in this Consulate:- Digest of the Invoice Book, Form No 117. Arrival and departure of vessels, ,, 120. Record of Notarial service, ,, 159. Summary of Consular Business, ,, 103. Ruled paper, both letter and foolscap. Envelopes, small, Legation and Consular. Inck, both black and red.
Glass on stone water jar and filter. (If a glass or stone one can not be obtained, any kind will do as the filter accompanies it. The water here is very impure and no suitable filter can be obtained.) (over.)

Sampe- 1 Bracket and 1 Table Sampe. Flag - 14 x 5 ft. 1 Rubber or Iron mat for outside door. 7 yds oil cloth 1 yd. wide for hall. 12 yds. stain carpeting or oil cloth 3/4 yards. 1 large carpit rug for middle of room Tacke.

Newspapers -- 1. Indianapolis Daily Journal. 2. Harper's Weekly. 3. London Times. Would like to have either the New York Herald or Washington Post instead of the other two foreigns papers referred to in Section 208 of Personal Instructions.
William D. McCoy, Minister Resident and Consul General to Liberia.
